summary: This document is a compilation of news articles from August 13-14, 2019, focused on the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody. It includes victim testimony from Jennifer Araoz, details of the jail security failures, political reactions, and updates on other unrelated SDNY cases. The document highlights the ongoing investigations into Epstein's death and the legal efforts to pursue his co-conspirators.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the case, found dead in his jail cell on August 10, 2019, while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges. Multiple articles discuss his crimes, the 2008 plea deal, and the circumstances of his death.

persons.name: Jennifer Araoz
persons.context: A woman who publicly accuses Epstein of raping her when she was 15, detailing her recruitment and abuse in a New York Times article. She is filing a civil action under the Child Victims Act.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Frequently mentioned in relation to the investigations into Epstein's death and the 2008 plea deal. He ordered the DOJ Inspector General to investigate and promised to pursue co-conspirators.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.context: Sent letters to Attorney General Barr urging him to 'rip up' Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement and demanding answers about the circumstances of Epstein's suicide in custody.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Repeatedly identified in the articles as Epstein's alleged 'madam' who recruited underage girls. She is reported to be living in Massachusetts with her new boyfriend, Scott Borgerson.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for Southern District of Florida, former Labor Secretary
persons.context: Mentioned as the prosecutor who negotiated the controversial 2008 non-prosecution agreement with Epstein, which led to his resignation as Labor Secretary.

persons.name: Lamine N'Diaye
persons.context: The warden of the MCC where Epstein died. He was temporarily reassigned to a Bureau of Prisons office in Philadelphia pending the outcome of investigations.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Mentioned as the prosecutor who vowed to continue the investigation into Epstein and his co-conspirators after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's younger brother. The article explores their business ties, noting Mark offered his Florida home for bond and discussing the connection between their companies.

persons.name: Scott Borgerson
persons.role: CEO of CargoMetrics Technologies, boyfriend of Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as the tech CEO with whom Ghislaine Maxwell is living in a Massachusetts mansion.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: Mentioned as Epstein's MC2 modeling agency business partner. An alleged victim claimed she was forced to have sex with him.

persons.name: Nadia Marcinkova
persons.context: Identified as a potential co-conspirator who operated a business registered at Mark Epstein's building.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Identified as a potential co-conspirator who operated a business registered at Mark Epstein's building.

persons.name: Ehud Barak
persons.context: Mentioned as having been photographed outside Jeffrey Epstein's townhouse and regularly spending time at Mark Epstein's condominium building.

persons.name: Ben Sprecher
persons.context: A Broadway producer arrested on federal child pornography charges, unrelated to the Epstein case but included in the news digest.

persons.name: Faheem Walter
persons.context: Tekashi69's former bodyguard sentenced for his role in a restaurant shooting, unrelated to Epstein but included in the news digest.

connections.description: Maxwell is repeatedly described as Epstein's closest associate, alleged 'madam,' and recruiter of underage victims for his sex trafficking ring.
Araoz accuses Epstein of raping her when she was 15 after being recruited by one of his associates.
Brothers. The document explores their business ties, including connections between their companies and the use of Mark's building for Epstein's associates.
Described as being in a relationship and living together in a Massachusetts mansion.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, negotiated the 2008 non-prosecution agreement that allowed Epstein to plead guilty to state charges.
Brunel was Epstein's partner in the MC2 modeling agency, which was allegedly used as part of the sex trafficking scheme.

events.title: Jennifer Araoz's abuse begins
events.description: Jennifer Araoz, then 14, is first recruited and begins visiting Jeffrey Epstein's Upper East Side mansion, where she is eventually raped.

events.title: Epstein's non-prosecution agreement
events.description: U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta negotiates a deal where Epstein pleads guilty to state charges, serves 13 months, and receives immunity for himself and potential co-conspirators from federal charges.

events.title: Epstein arrested on federal charges
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is arrested on federal sex trafficking charges in New York.

events.title: Epstein's first suicide attempt in custody
events.description: Epstein is found injured in his cell at the MCC and placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein found dead in jail cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center and is later pronounced dead. The death is ruled an apparent suicide by hanging.

events.title: Jail guards placed on leave, warden reassigned
events.description: Two MCC guards are placed on administrative leave for failing to check on Epstein and falsifying logs. Warden Lamine N'Diaye is temporarily reassigned.

events.title: Jennifer Araoz files civil action
events.description: Jennifer Araoz announces she is filing a civil lawsuit against Epstein's estate and accomplices under New York's Child Victims Act.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), Manhattan, New York
Epstein's mansion, Upper East Side, Manhattan, New York
301 East 66th Street, Manhattan, New York (building owned by Mark Epstein)
Manchester-by-the-Sea, Massachusetts (mansion where Ghislaine Maxwell is reportedly living)
Palm Beach, Florida (location of another Epstein mansion)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019, in an apparent suicide by hanging.
Two guards assigned to watch Epstein fell asleep and failed to check on him for about three hours, then falsified logs to cover it up. They were placed on administrative leave.
Jennifer Araoz publicly accused Epstein of raping her when she was 15 and detailed a pattern of recruitment and abuse beginning in 2001.
Senator Ben Sasse urged Attorney General William Barr to 'rip up' Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement to allow for the prosecution of co-conspirators.
Ghislaine Maxwell, Epstein's alleged 'madam,' was reported to be living in seclusion in a Massachusetts mansion with tech CEO Scott Borgerson.
